text: Serve–receive shape: your serve_middle most often drew lifts/cross‑lifts; the best third‑touch windows appeared when you took the exchange to net.
Finish vs errors: you 25 winners vs 29 errors; finishes clustered on forehand_smash_cross and overhead_drop_cross; errors on overhead_drop_cross, overhead_smash, backhand_defense.
Court geography: winning hotspot at front_right; losing hotspot at back_left; most effective in middle_center (flat_game), most ineffective at middle_left (backhand_defense).
First reply vs opponent serve: forehand_dribble stabilized starts and set a net‑front tempo.
Championship control: Net Battle into timely depth and net closes held late passages.
Height conversion: when rallies produced height, forehand_smash/forehand_smash_cross finished cleanly.
Middle_left scrambles: backhand_defense lanes ceded initiative and preceded opponent pressure chains.
Back_left finals: pressured overhead endings bled points in decisive moments.
Early forehand_lift_cross in open rallies invited opponent smash/drive chains.
On your serve: sequences swung your way when the third touch reached a clean net hold after their lift/cross‑lift.
On their serve: returns starting with forehand_dribble more often kept the rally in your net‑front window.
End‑phase shot selection: late overhead_drop_cross outcomes skewed negative compared to net finishes and smash conversion.
